    Releasing Hotfixes

    Source: vignettes/hotfixes.qmd

    This document is adapted for The Hubverse from The Carpentries Developer’s Handbook (c) The Carpentries under the CC-BY 4.0 license.

    Introduction

    A hotfix is a bug fix for a situation where a bug has been found, but the main branch has new features that are not yet ready to be released.

    A process for creating a hotfix release is similar to that of the standard release with the following differences:

    standard hotfix
    parent branch main <tag>
    tag and release after merge before merge
    merge conflicts never with DESCRIPTION and NEWS.md

    An example of good candidate for a hotfix in the hubverse is hubValidations issue #123. This bug was discovered in hubValidations 0.6.2. However, this was after the main branch had unreleased features. While the new features were stable, the documentation was not fully polished1. A hotfix would give developers more time to document the new feature.

    While this bug fix was released through the standard release process, It could have easily been a hotfix release. This chapter will be a walkthrough of the hotfix process if it had been applied in hubValidations pull request 124.

    Conventions

    This walkthrough will be presented as if our lead developer, Anna Krystalli were fixing the bug (which she did in real life!) via this hotfix process. We will diagram the process using the following conventions:

    • Each step will be written in the second person perspective

    • The commit IDs and branch names are simplified and will not directly match the real life names

      • Each new commit is a unique sequence of letters
      • Each merge commit is a combination of letters from the two previous commits

    • Each non-main branch will be prefixed with ak/

    • The command prompt will be displayed in the following format

      $ (<branch>) <COMMAND> # comment about <COMMAND>
#| output of <COMMAND>

    The Scenario

    • hubValidations 0.6.2 was released on 2024-09-20.
    • the create_custom_check() function was merged into hubValidations 0.6.2.9000 on 2024-10-01 after it had been tested and validated.
    • the vignette for creating custom validations was being drafted in a separate branch on 2024-10-01.
    • A bug was discovered in hubValidations 0.6.2 on 2024-10-02.

    This is what the state of the project would look like on 2024-10-02 (simplified):

    The rest of the walkthrough will detail the four steps required to fix the bug.

    Step 1: Create a Fix and Pull Request

    Normally, to fix bugs, you would check out a new bugfix branch from the main branch. Here’s the catch: if you check out from the main branch you will grab ak/create-fun/121 as well, which is not yet ready for production because you intended ak/document-fun/121 to be released along side. In this case, you need to create a hotfix, and create the branch from the last tag (which in this case is v0.6.2).

    IMPORTANT: When you create a hotfix, name the branch <author>/hotfix/<issue>. By using /hotfix/ in the branch name, the GitHub workflows will know to test this package against the released versions from the R-universe.

    (main)$ git describe
#| v0.6.2-3-ggpne
(main)$ git switch --detach v0.6.2 # checkout the tag
#| HEAD is now at efgh Merge pull request #119 from hubverse-org/ak/release/v0.6.2
((v0.6.2))$ git switch -c ak/hotfix/123 # create a new branch
#| switched to new branch 'ak/hotfix/123'
(ak/hotfix/123)$ git push -u origin ak/hotfix/123 # push the branch to GitHub

    Now you are ready to iterate and fix the bug on the hotfix branch, adding the test and then adding the fix and any documentation to go with it.

    When you have finished iterating on your own and are satisfied that it works, the next step is to open a pull request and get a review.

    Step 2: Ensure checks pass, get a review, and create tag

    You should check that the hotfix does not break any existing tests, which are automatically run from the pull request. Once you have confirmed that everything works as expected and have an approving review, the next step is to bump the version and add a tag. This tag will allow you to release the patch version.

    (ak/hotfix/123)$ git add DESCRIPTION NEWS.md
(ak/hotfix/123)$ git commit -m 'bump version to v0.6.3'
(ak/hotfix/123)$ git tag -s v0.6.3 -m 'hotfix: validate tasks with optional output types'
(ak/hotfix/123)$ git push
(ak/hotfix/123)$ git push --tags

    **Note the v0.6.3 tag is on the ak/hotfix/123 branch at the bottom.

    At this point, the checks will not run on the pull request because there will be a conflict in the DESCRIPTION and NEWS.md files. This is okay. All you did was update the version numbers and add NEWS. Do not merge at this point. The next step is to release the patch.

    Step 3: Release the Patch

    You will release the patch using the same method as described in the releases chapter. You can either release on GitHub directly or via the GitHub CLI. Importantly, when you create the release, you should create the release from the new tag. This can be done via the GitHub interface or using GitHub’s CLI tool.

    (ak/hotfix/123)$ gh release create v0.6.3

    Step 4: Resolve Conflicts and Merge

    Now that you’ve created the release, you should resolve the conflicts in the DESCRIPTION and NEWS files and then merge it back into main (note: this will create two merge commits, but I’m only showing one in the diagram to make it cleaner):

    Now you will have the patch in place for the released version and the devel version of this hubverse package, which means that you can continue to develop as normal and merge the next feature when you are ready:

    On this page
